greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of permutations of {1..n} at Kendall tau distance k of permutation sigma1 and k+1 Kendall tau distance of permutation sigma2, where sigma1 and sigma2 are at Kendall tau distance 1.
comment: The length of the n-th row is n(n-1)/2 + 1, where n(n-1)/2 is the maximum Kendall tau distance distance for permutations of {1..n}.
link: María Merino, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20875 (rows n = 1..50, flattened)
formula: T(n,k) = Sum_{j=0..k} (-1)^j * S(n,k-j), where S(n,k) = A008302(n,k) is the number of permutations of {1..n} with k inversions.
mathematica: T[n_] := Module[{polcoef, svalues = {}, si, j, k, c}, polcoef = CoefficientList[Series[QFactorial[n, c], {c, 0, n (n - 1)/2}], c]; For[j = 1, j <= Length[polcoef], j++, si = 0; For[k = 1, k <= j, k++, si = si + polcoef[[k]]*(-1)^(j - k)]; AppendTo[svalues, si]]; Return[svalues]]; Catenate[Table[T[n], {n, 1, 7}]]
program: (PARI) S(n, k) = my(A=1+x); for(i=1, n, A = 1 + intformal(A - q*subst(A, x, q*x +x^2*O(x^n)))/(1-q)); polcoeff(n!*polcoeff(A, n, x), k, q); \\ A008302
tabf(nn) = for (n=1, nn, for (k=0, n*(n-1)/2, print1(T(n, k), ", ")); print); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Apr 10 2019
results.author: Imanol Unanue, _María Merino_, Jose A. Lozano, Apr 08 2019
